newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Howard wishes Major good luck.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Howard wishes Major good luck.

text.p: Australian Prime Minister John Howard, a conservative riding high in the polls after a year in office, called Britain's John Major on Wednesday to wish him luck in May 1 elections expected to end 18 years of Tory rule.

Howard -- a stolid politician not unlike Britain's "grey man prime minister" -- told Major it was a good idea to take part in a public debate with Labour leader Tony Blair, a government spokesman told Reuters.
"Major said the economy was in the best shape it had been in 70 years, so they thought that was a message they could sell (to voters)," the spokesman said.
Britain's Labour opposition, around 25 percentage points ahead in opinion polls, is widely expected to end the Conservatives' 18-year grip on power.
For most of that period -- from 1983 to 1996 -- Australia was ruled by its own leftist Labor party.
But Howard's Liberal-Nationals crushed Labor last March and now hold 94 of the 147 seats in the lower House of Representatives.
Given that majority, political analysts say Howard's conservative coalition is likely to hold government for six years (two terms) and might easily remain for nine.
